page.title: 01Around Buttermere, Wiltshire
page.content: Buttermere, by the still used ancient right of way along the top of the downs, is mainly agricultural with crops, cattle and sheep. There are about 18 houses approximately a third of which are occupied by commuters to London or nearby towns, a few used as weekend homes and the rest by the land owners and farm employees. The water is pumped up the hill from the nearby village of Shalbourne, drainage is by septic tank. There is mains electricity, though the church, which only has services once a month from May to October, is still lit by candles and oil lamps. There are many ancient hedgerows, tumuli and earthworks still in the area. Four very old yew trees in Buttermere Wood have many superstitions attached to them, local people not liking to go there after dark. A ghost of an old
